title: Polish Read Speech Corpus for Speech Tools and Services

author: Danijel Koržinek, Polish-Japanese Academy of Information Technology

segmentation: Hello, I'm here.
On behalf of a team from Warsaw.
We are part of the Clarion project.
So for the beginning I.

Wanted to just share a little bit of information about our project and what we do in Poland and for anyone that is not aware cloud in Poland is basically has started around 2013 if I'm correct, more or less and we have managed to finish one part of the project and we have.
We're just beginning our second part so the first part of the project was mostly concentrating on.
And the infrastructure on setting up all the tools and services and this talk is going to be mostly technical, so there are a few applications that we have managed to.

I mean, there are a few projects we have managed to use our tools on so far, but this is mostly going to be on things that we have set up, so there's various teams in the project and doing dealing with most various topics like related to linguistics, social linguistics, there's even a little bit about language translation.
But our team in Warsaw is dealing with the speech.
And.
Basically, the motivation for obvious which would probably be obvious to most people here.

The motivation for doing such research is because a lot of data that exist in is mostly is sometimes in the form of pure audio, and for most human humanities and social Sciences researchers, this can be really difficult thing to handle because processing such data can be quite expensive.
Using translation or transcription services can be expensive.

But even if somebody wants to do it themselves because they don't have any funding at all, can take a lot of time and requires a lot of knowledge and know how, especially in sort of challenging languages like Polish, because the technology is still not there.
It is not as ubiquitous As for example, in English or German.
So This is why we try to provide these services for free.
So anybody, everybody would have access to them.
We have mostly two areas that we concentrate on and this is kind of separate this into data and tools and we do have a website set up for anyone who wants to see.
So far the website is in Polish because this is like in the first part of the project we wanted to set everything up but we are working on translating it into English as well.
So the first part of my presentation is going to be on data and.
The kind of motivations again for creating.
Data is because when we started working, we already had quite an experience with creating various tools.

And we are aware also that we're not the only one who should be making these tools in Poland, so the situation currently is that a lot of the data for creating these tools to process speech is actually very expensive and hard to get.
Some of it is commercial.
An obviously costs a lot of money, but even this stuff that is created in recent fairly recently in projects like Metanet.
And so on.

Is pretty domain limited and cannot be really used for making generic high quality tools, so our goals was to create kind of the first, completely free general purpose speech corpus for creating like these baseline tools that can be later used to adapt to specific domains.
So and also 11 remark is that?
Well, there is obviously data available for free, because you can always download it from various websites and so on.
The problem with that is that it is usually also restricted.
So the way we decided to create our corpus was.
Basically, well, what is kind of very well known today.

An speech technology communities to basically record a red corpus to invite as many people as we can to to the studio, and this way we kind of got everyone's consent to actually publish this data for one and also the data is not in any way personal or related to the speakers, so.
The corpus that we created is well compared to the last presentation.

It doesn't seem like a lot 5656 hours may seem like a small number, but it is actually quite sufficient to create some pretty decent tools, especially because the quality is very controlled in this situation and we also created a little smaller sub corpus.
It was recorded over telephony, kind of.
An situations because the acoustic environment there is completely different and there are some use cases that call for analyzing such data.
So the the main purpose of this corpus was to to develop speech tools, speech processing tools.
So in itself it's not maybe very valuable resource for humanities research apart from maybe some very low level phonetics research and stuff like that.
Nevertheless we are releasing it in two forms.
One of them is a very popular system called MMU Emo.
I'm not sure.
And that currently is released in a in a.
Old kind of format that you had to download a program and install locally on your computer.
And download the whole database which is a few gigabytes and it's not really may be convenient for all the users, but we are currently.
Working in something that is.
As I have learned, a really popular also among other.

Participants of the project and that is to use the web interface, which would be really convenient thing for people where you could just log into the website and browse the data directly on the website.
Furthermore, there is also this.
This service also has some really interesting connections to the R statistics package, which allows to do some really nice and easy.
Hypothesis testing and so on on the data.
Anne.
We also are releasing the Speech Recognition Toolkit.
Completely prepared for download.
Basically the way this works.
These are some of the results, just some of the baseline results that you can get from the system.
But basically, the way it works is for the technical minded people.
All you have to do is just clone repository.
Practically, run a single command and after a couple of hours depending on the computer you have, you can get a completely working system to set up locali.
Or maybe to do some kind of research and tweaking for some specific use.
Anne.
So as I mentioned this, this speech corpus was mostly done for creating tools, but we are working now.
We have started working mostly with other partners of the project and creating some domain specific corpora and a couple of them.
Shown here is a corpus of spontaneous speech which is quite a challenging task because the recording quality on such corpora is usually very questionable.
They are usually recorded.

An semi hidden so people may not even be aware that they are being recorded at the current moment, that that is because the microphone is not really in Clearview so the quality of these recordings is very challenging.
But we're going to do our best to kind of annotate as much as the data is much of this data as possible.
Apart from that we have something that is really popular among researchers and this is the parliamentary data.
And finally, we also have a collection of historical videos which are kind of like new segments that you would find.
Played in in the from like the early, maybe even the 50s and 60s all the way until today.
That would talk about current events and this seems to be a very useful resource for several reasons.
For one, it doesn't seem to be as complicated to automatically process because it has usually a single.
Person speaking about these events and second of all, it does have a really wide historical context, and there's a lot of interesting information that can be extracted from that.
Ann for the second part of the.
Yeah presentation.
I'm going to kind of glance over these things.
We have obviously released all these tools and services for people to use an our kind of idea was to start from basically everything that we have, and maybe this isn't a very.
Kind of a smart thing to do, but we basically looked at the speech processing tool chain that we kind of usually use to extract data from from audio and.
We kind of took the several apart from just giving the transcription.
We kind of took the several intermediary steps and also kind of provided them as services for anyone to use if they want separately.
So these tools included.
Maybe it's not very visible on that.
Slide, but these two tools include things like grapheme to phoneme conversion.

Uh, speech alignment speaker diarization voice activity detection, keyword spotting and finally something that we didn't really plan to do, but we're currently working on is actual speech transcription.
There are other initiatives, including that are actually working on these things as well.
I'm not going to go into a.
Lot of technical details.
I'm just going to mention because of the time limitations.

What these still actually do so grapheme to phoneme conversion is obviously conversion from the orthographic to phonetic alphabet, something that is fairly simple to do in Polish using a finite set of rules, except for obviously all the exceptions that occur in noisy textual data, an foreign words and so on, so most of it works fairly well, but we have to do a lot of exception to deal with these foreign languages and.
A noise occurring in.
Data, the most useful tool.
The most well working tool in our opinion is obviously speech segmentation, so I use this term text to speech alignment because it's usually more easy to understand for humanities researchers.

So basically, if we do have audio and text that we can fairly accurately give an alignment of when each word, an even phoning occurs in this audio segment, and this does work fairly well even for long audio.
Anne.

Voice activity detection is something that is kind of a standard component of any speech recognition process, and we do have some extra tweaks that could be useful to people, but this is a fairly not very not very often requested tool.
Speaker Diarization is something that is more interesting to people and people have asked for such tools.
So basically there are several levels that you could detect.
Speakers you have speaker change detection, speaker, diarization or even speaker identification.
Well, we don't do actual speaker identification.
We don't actually know who is speaking at the moment, but we do try to at least say that the same speaker, whoever it is, occurs several times in one piece of recording.
And this this could be useful too to some people that we talked to.
Keyword detection in this case is basically just a slightly simpler version of speech transcription.

If people are only interested in finding certain keywords, than this is a slightly easier task because we can get a little bit well depending on the keyword, we can get a little bit better results for detecting a specific keyword than detecting every word in the sentence so.
But this works mostly the same way as finally.
Transcription, which is one of the most requested tools.
Obviously for a lot of researchers and the problem here is that.
This tool to work accurately.
It does require a lot of adaptation.
So here are a couple of applications that we have managed to do, so we did work on the content and the spontaneous speech corpus.

We also had a project with the Institute of Applied Linguistics to work on some data that they were recording for Re speaking that I can mention if anybody is interested and we have made attempts to transcribe things like social science interviews which we actually had.
Well, it wasn't very easy.
Just just to say, but we did manage to in some specific cases to actually provide some tools that do work for such data.
So for future plans, we do intend to add additional corpora to process this additional corpora too.
I adapt our tools for various domains and we generally have a strategy where we try to 1st talk to the people and ask for their data and then provide them with some working solutions.
We want to also improve some of the usability issues with these services because we recognize that this is also a very big problem.
And.

We basically want to kind of facilitate create more cooperation with partners, so we are actively looking for people in the Community to work with and we do get emails occasionally, so this isn't very difficult.
Fortunately, and we hope we hope that this is going to.
Get better with time, thank you.
